SCHOLARNOTE.P: During her first marriage she published as Gladys Mendl.

SHORTPROSE.P: The British Library Catalogue in 2009 returned no results for GHS on a search for Schutze (which returns results for others bearing the name of Schütze) or Schuetze. It listed her works (except those published as Gladys Mendl) under the name of Henrietta Leslie, which she adopted as her pen-name in 1916.

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: Gladys Henrietta Raphael (later Schütze), an only child, was born at 42 Portland Place, London.

SHORTPROSE.P: Her family were British members of prosperous, successful Jewry. In 1884 D'Israeli had only been dead four years and tolerance was very much the order of the day. So that anti-semitism was at a very low ebb. It was also an age of prosperity, security and progress. A golden age. 9 At least some of her relations were Orthodox, but Gladys Henrietta rejected Orthodoxy for herself because she hated the prescribed wig which one of her married aunts wore over her shaved head. When, years later, she discovered the movement for women's suffrage, she straight away remembered the image of this aunt. In 1923, largely influenced by the pacifism of the Rev. Dick Sheppard, Schütze became a convert to the Church of England. As the persecution of European Jews escalated during the 1930s, however, she rediscovered her Jewish identity as something which, in solidarity, she needed to assert.

GHS involved herself with the Liberal Party in about 1906, and the Women's Social and Political Union soon afterwards. She worked with the Pankhursts and militant suffragettes. During World War One, prejudice against her husband's German name caused her to be ejected from the Society of Women Journalists even though she was, and painfully remained throughout the war, a pacifist. This commitment led her to persist for a long time in believing that a second world war could be avoided. When she realised at last that it could not, she sadly laid aside her pacifist beliefs for the conviction that armed resistance to Nazi and fascist regimes was right and necessary.

GHS's early memories of her mother, Marianna Florette (Moses) Raphael, pictured a dazzling vision in a flame-red silk dress, coming to say good-night on her way to a party, beautiful and quick in mind, movement, and temper.10-11 Left a young widow, Marianna became a remarkably successful painter, a friend of artists—and a bicyclist. She was a strict parent (making lunch a purgatory, for instance, by insisting on speaking French one day and German the next). Her daughter felt she was being judged inadequate.22-3, 34, 43

GHS's father, Arthur Lewis Raphael, was tall, kindly, musical, athletic, and unable to say no.10-11 When she was about six he lost his job with the family firm because of his heavy losses in betting on horses. He was thus a family scandal when, very soon afterwards, he fell ill and suddenly died, leaving a rift between his widow and his own family which never fully healed.20

Gladys Henrietta's maternal grandfather, Assur Moses, who was widowed long before she was born, was a most strictly observing Jew of the old-fashioned type, although he was progressive and open-minded in matters that did not concern religion.13 He was the grandparent she particularly cherished.23 His friends came from many countries and from different faiths. His family included German, Spanish, and Portuguese Jews, who shared all the national characteristics of the countries they inhabited, and had done so for generations.14 They had no contact with the poor Jews of East London.12-14
GHS's paternal grandfather, on the other hand, invited her to occasional, formal lunches, without her mother, which she did not enjoy.24-5

Gladys Henrietta was never very strong. She nearly died of peritonitis at a few months old, and acquired a hip injury, which troubled her all her life, apparently from a fall out of her pram. It began to pain her a few years later, and she had to use a wheel-chair, then crutches, then sticks, with each of which she prided herself on moving faster than other crippled children.18, 25 She fell seriously ill again just before she left her first marriage.83

Gladys Henrietta had her portrait painted as a child, probably about 1889, by Solomon J. Solomon. She sat again to J. J. Shannon during her engagement, by which time she had come out and been formally presented to the queen, finding the curtsey difficult in her therapeutic high boot. Despite her disability she was able to play golf and tennis, though ski-ing defeated her.frontispiece, 9, 45, 47, 59
In her earliest memories her family was wealthy. After her father died, she and her mother became comparatively poor.10-11, 20-1

GHS was educated at home by governesses of several nationalities: Mademoiselle Titsie, Marie Girard, Rose Frohnstein, and the English M. L. J., on several of whom she lavished that warmth of temperament which her mother repressed. Influential among her early reading, and crucial in forming her pacifist beliefs, was The Conquest of Mexico by William Hickling Prescott. She also read Emerson's essays and Walter Pater's Marius the Epicurean, but did not understand them. An old rabbi came to teach her Hebrew until she turned against Judaism over its treatment of women. Notwithstandng her forays into history and literature, she later judged that her middle-class schoolroom education had left her with yawning gaps in her knowledge.21, 28, 30-3

Her formal teaching was dominated by music. For singing one of her teachers was one de Soria who was said to be the original of Glorioli in Du Maurier's Trilby; another was Paolo Tosti. She learned piano from Carlo Albanesi. Such distinguished teachers, she said, were an index less of her talent than of her mother's ambition for her.15-16, 36-7
The Raphael family occupied a large house in Portland Place till her father died. Then a smaller London house was necessary: first in Hamilton Terrace, then at 2 Hanover Terrace in Regent's Park.

While her father lived they spent their highly sociable summers at one or other rented house in the country.16 Afterwards the child spent winters, for her health, at one or other seaside town, beginning with St Leonards. Later again their holidays were divided between Capel Curig in Wales and St Lawrence on the Isle of Wight, where they rented Craigie Lodge from the parents of the woman writer John Oliver Hobbes.20-1, 27-8, 40-1

DIV1.HEADING: First Marriage; Discovering Politics and Friendship

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: Seventeen-year-old Henrietta Raphael (later GHS) married Louis Mendl (a corn merchant whose elder brother was her uncle by marriage) and discovered what it means to grow up in a night, as she put it later.

SHORTPROSE.P: Their engagement of over a year was marked by formal visits to all their relations (on Sunday for the orthodox, Saturday for the others). She and her chaperone occupied one hansom cab, Louis another, since some family members would have been scandalised if the couple had shared a cab before their marriage.46 This was in many ways a traditional wedding: within the family circle, with a young woman who was both sexually and practically ignorant. Gladys Henrietta left her husband in1910, having rejected the belief that woman's place is in the home.

She, who had never left the house alone or paid a bill, was now responsible for her husband's finances as well as her own, for entertaining lavishly without running in debt, and for chaperoning unmarried women older than she was. She also branched out, running subscription dances to raise money for the Hoxton Babies' Home founded by William Pett Ridge.58-9, 63

Gladys Henrietta Mendl (later GHS) began married life in a large house in Gloucester Place, with five maids.48 She spent her first winter as a married woman, however, in the city of Galatz in Romania, on the banks of the Danube, where her husband was sent to help with the family business. Here she felt, despite wide European travels, that she had never known what it was to be a stranger before coming to this place where she knew nothing of the language and was shocked by the gulf between rich and poor.52-3 Their return to London felt like the end of a holiday, as she struggled to get to grips with large-scale housekeeping.
During her time at Galatz in Romania, she visited Russia by walking illicitly across the frozen Danube.55

GHS became a pro-Boer when the Boer war was ending, having studied the imperial project in The Conquest of Mexico by William Hickling Prescott. More broadly, this study and its application gave her a deep-rooted horror of war.33 At this time she felt, however, that we never can have a war here, in England. People like us don't have wars, only savages.34

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: Henrietta Mendl (later GHS) campaigned for the Liberals before the general election held on 7 February, in which her brother-in-law Sigi Mendl was standing for the Liberals at Stockton-on-Tees.

SHORTPROSE.P: She already thought of herself as a Radical and was sorry when Sigi failed owing to the splitting of the progressive vote. Her work for him included holding a hostile crowd with her words while her relation the Liberal candidate failed to show up as promised (he had in fact been more or less kidnapped by people on the other side).70, 81 After having been active for the Liberals, GHS began to work with the Women's Social and Political Union. Convinced of the justice of the case for women's suffrage, she gradually came to accept the necessity of direct action and even the resort to violence.

She worked with Emmeline and Christabel Pankhurst, and became a militant suffragette. Like Constance Lytton, she overcame both natural timidity and physical frailty to take part in demonstrations which were often met with a violent response from police. She was once painfully ejected from a meeting after formally refusing, according to suffrage policy, to shake Asquith's hand till you give women the vote.71 She was never arrested, partly through the good advice of a London policeman, Donald Taylor, who married one of her maids and lived in fear of having to take her into custody.48-9

GHS's first suffrage meeting, in fact, became a deputation heading for the House of Commons, where it was met by violence. She dreamed about the event that night and joined the WSPU next day. But for the next two years (while her first marriage was ending) she did little for the suffrage, being too unhappy and too much in need of distraction though pleasure-seeking.76, 78
On the occasion of this deputation to the king, GHS received a kick from a police horse which caused her bad hip to flare up and from which she never entirely recovered..109-10
The hip remained a source of pain and intermittent disability for the rest of her life.

Through her early mentor W. Pett Ridge GHS met various literary men: W. W. Jacobs, Barry Pain, Jerome K. Jerome, Hugh Walpole, and Ernest Temple Thurston. Pett Ridge (P. R.) was generous with career advice as well as philanthropy, but was very difficult as a friend. She took it with equanimity when he dropped her flat and much later restarted the friendship equally unexpectedly.63-7 She met Henry Nevinson when her aunt Betsy Raphael (whose son Jack was also her good friend) took her to her first suffrage meeting.75 She came to know Emmeline Pankhurst (whom she found tender and human)96 and Christabel Pankhurst (the brains of the movement, but hard and ruthless).95 Emmeline, having won the near hero-worship of GHS and her husband, lost it again after war broke out and suffrage was being put aside for patriotism, by making an unpleasant remark about [p]eople with German names.110 GHS contrasts her with Emmeline Pethick-Lawrence, who combined pacifism with her suffragism (though she was never bitter towards non-pacifists).110

GHS also knew and loved the great Olive Schreiner.128-9 Vernon Lee, she said, was primarily a friend of her scientist husband; they both stayed with her several times. Schütze pondered the paradox of Lee's intellectual brilliance and colourless appearance. Her friendships with these two women influenced both her political thinking and her growing ambition to become a writer. The suffragist Florence White (sister of writer Percy White) became and remained a close friend.
It is unlikely that the Florence White mentioned by GHS is cookbook writer Florence Louisa White (1863-1940). She is more probably the suffragist Florence White (1886-1961), daughter of James and Caroline White, who founded the National Spinsters' Pension Association in 1935. In 1941, the British government lowered the age of retirement for women to sixty as a result of the successful lobbying of White and the NSPA about the financial plight of older unmarried working women.St John Ervine became a friend with whom GHA regrettably fell out in the end.115-19, 51 Later the pacifist leader the Rev. Dick Sheppard became a great friend of mine, by which I mean someone who counted greatly in my life, though she never really felt she knew him.155 She met Isadora Duncan as a journalist, and felt that the dancer was a spiritual force for good.167-8

On her first attendance at PEN, taken there by an American friend, Sarah MacConnell, she met Catharine Amy Dawson Scott (whom she took to at once), Galsworthy (whose work she much admired), Roma Wilson, Anna Wickham, and May Sinclair.213-16
During these years GHS became a journalist and also published her first novels.

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: After beginning her life in politics, GHS married Dr Harry Leslie Hugo Schütze (always known as Peter), whom she describes as an Australian bacteriologist.83 He was of German descent, and was only a couple of years older than herself.

SCHOLARNOTE.P: The ODNB gives this form of his name, but his wife addressed him in print by the initials H. R. L. S.

SHORTPROSE.P: Born and educated through secondary school in Australia, he had left at twenty-two to travel and study in Europe. He then studied bacteriology at Würzburg in Germany (his father's country of origin), took his first job there, then after his mother died came to work at the Lister Institute in Chelsea, and published research in his field.85-6 He was a suffragist who supported his wife's political activism and on one occasion intervened to protect her from arrest. Both of them suffered from the anti-German feeling in England during the First World War. The marriage was childless; when GHS considered her mother's over-anxious parentlng she sometimes felt that this might be a good thing.22-3
Peter's brother Gus joined the second world war on the German side, and was eventually killed. This was one of the painful events that fed into Mrs. Fischer's War.132

The seventeenth-century Glebe House in Chelsea became GHS's home after her second marriage and remained so for the rest of her life. On moving in they painted the walls in strong, pure colours. She and her husband also had a country house. For a while during the suffrage struggle they rented Stockenden near Oxted in Surrey, a Tudor house close to that of the Macrae sisters (Georgie, Helen, and Betty), who served the movement by offering a rest in the country to suffragettes worn down by campaigning. The Schützes were often at Stockenden during the first world war.88-90, 131
GHS later attended PEN conferences at Barcelona and Paris, in Hungary and in Poland. At Barcelona she was a joint delegate with E. M. Delafield.219, 221, 223

Peter Schütze, being Australian, thought it natural for women to have the vote, and understood that the tactic of violence was chosen only in desperation when everything else had failed.93-4 GHS took an increasingly active role in the campaign, and to her pride and terror was selected as a courier to carry incriminating documents to Paris, secreted about her person (rolled up in her hair, and sewn into the seams of an overcoat which she felt to be all too obviously not her own). After a journey of pure agony96 she arrived with her secrets undiscovered at Christabel Pankhurst's Paris flat, to be treated like a machine by Christabel though with human kindness by Ethel Smyth (who was also present), and sent back again with more secret documents the next morning. Another job she hated but was very good at was selling copies of The Suffragette while moving constantly forward so as not to be defined as causing an obstruction;96-9 another was interrupting church services to insert an extra prayer in the Litany, for those in prison, suffering for conscience sake.99

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: Emmeline Pankhurst, just released from prison under the Cat and Mouse Act because of her fragile condition, needed a place to hold a meeting without being arrested, and GHS's house was chosen.

SHORTPROSE.P: Schütze cancelled engagements at short notice, kept her servants indoors, and smuggled in food to feed a couple of dozen people who slept on her floors after the meeting. Mrs Pankhurst made her speech from the balcony, but because of the strong police presence had to stay a whole day longer than planned, before making a successful escape (after Florence White, a near-double of Pankhurst, had tried to decoy police away, but failed). The Schützes were left shattered—but their suffragist cook, Mrs Duckett, was wildly exhilarated. Duckett went on to become the only woman besides Emmeline Pankhurst to succeed in getting through the gates of Buckingham Palace on a suffrage deputation to the king.102-10

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: Sure that the socialists of the world would never stand for war, GHS, her husband, her father-in-law, and Florence White, set off for their planned holiday in Holland; hostile incidents multiplied and they beat an anxious retreat.

SHORTPROSE.P: She used their experience—and the later, small but painful episodes of anti-German prejudice in England—in Mrs. Fischer's War, where the protagonist's precarious situation makes such things more serious and threatening.

During World War One GHS became and remained a fully convinced pacifist, as did her husband. Years later, with Nazi Germany re-arming, she reluctantly ceased to be a pacifist. She resigned, painfully, from Dick Sheppard's Peace Pledge Union, sorry to hurt those of her friends who were still pacifists, but sure that pacifism was no longer a sane option.111-15, 125-7, 134-5

During the Schützes' pacifist years it was only gradually that they began to find some support from like-minded people, like Bertrand Russell and Ramsay MacDonald (though GHS felt the latter was a fair-weather pacifist). On holiday in Italy she met the future Field-Marshal Montgomery and, greatly daring, tried to convert him to the idea of disarmament.125-7, 233

GHS was ejected during the first world war from the professional associations which she belonged to as a writer and journalist, the Society of Women Journalists and the Literary Club. This action resulted from her husband's German blood and name rather than from her pacifism, though at this time of xenophobic patriotism that too was an additional cause of suspicion. (The ODNB points out that she and her husband shared with Olive Schreiner their ostracism for combining a German name with pacifist principles.)

After the war, in 1919, GHS pursued regular journalistic work as well as her own writing. For the socialist Weekly Herald she worked at the invitation of W. N. Ewer, combing European newspapers in German, French, and Italian for news-items which the non-socialist British press had overlooked. She found the paper's offices deafening and the cheap newsprint (especially of the German papers) blinding. She soon resigned and became instead a newspaper reporter for the sister Daily Herald, working for Gerald Gould. Despite some snubs and some painful experiences (for instance with the anti-feminist News Editor William Mellor), she loved this exciting work. Other contributors included Evelyn Sharp and Eleanor Farjeon. After Schütze gave up her regular work in journalism she continued to do freelance jobs.136-44, 153, 155, 160-1

When she ceased being a journalist, in 1923, she volunteered to her services to Eglantyne Jebb, joint-founder with her sister Dorothy Buxton of the Save the Children Fund, as an honorary organizer. She calls Jebb one of greatest spiritual forces that has taken human shape in the past nineteen hundred and forty-two years.189-90 She began working and travelling abroad for Save the Children, and held her position with it for nine years. She held fund-raising events, gathered donations from writers, and worked with a fund to protect German children against the worst of the poverty and starvation in that country under the terms of the peace treaty. This succouring of the recent enemy was controversial, but it made GHS aware of the needs generated by what today are called humanitarian emergencies.187, 176

Having, as a member from its early years of the P. E. N. Club (later PEN International), supported writers persecuted for their opinions, GHS began in the 1930s to work for refugees from Nazi Germany (mostly Jewish). She personally provided accommodation for many of them, both in London and at her country home.

GHS later developed fresh trouble with her bad hip, which flared up painfully. She spent three months in a so-called extension, with my head lower than my heels, and the three months after that, I devoted to learning to walk again.161 Her disabiity, which made paid work difficult, encouraged her in her voluntary activities. Periods of intense and concentrated writing continued to be hard for her. In winter 1933 she crocked up13 after working too hard to finish her book on Bulgaria.12-13

While working for the Daily Herald GHS developed the habit of dropping into St Martin-in-the-Fields for the peace and quiet. Thus she met the Rev. Dick Sheppard, who was one influence towards her conversion to Anglican Christianity. She could give no answer to a friend who asked her why,155-8 except: The figure of Christ.158 She was happy in her spiritual life for years, until the rise of Hitler began turning the whole world race-conscious. Then she began to feel an overpowering urge to proclaim my Jewish origin.159

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: GHS travelled to Bulgaria to report for Save the Children on the conditions there following a severe earthquake.

SHORTPROSE.P: She was twice in Bulgaria, once for this relief work and then again to gather material for a book about the country.viii

She reported in another slight but delightful book some foreign holidays apart from humanitarian work, taken in Italy, Yugoslavia, Austria, Morocco, Wales, Scotland, Ireland, Holland, islands in the Mediterranean, Norway, Sweden, Corsica, and Russia.vii-viii240-1
The play based on Mrs. Fischer's War brought GHS an important friendship: that with a theatre business manager, William Barry.235
At Glebe House in Chelsea, GHS and her husband kept several servants (some of whom became friends) and enjoyed giving dinner parties for eight people, which was considered a small gathering.13-14

During Storm Jameson's presidency of the English branch of PEN International (which began early in 1938) the Schützes lent Glebe House for a two-day sale raising funds for refugees from the Nazis. GHS, who was the chief organizer, had to cope when the singer Fritzi Massary (with whom she had already had professional difficulties) reneged on an undertaking to speak, and then said she had not realised that the sale was to benefit refugees.239

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: GHS and her husband travelled to New York to help represent PEN International at the World's Fair there, the largest ever held.

SHORTPROSE.P: When Britain and France declared war on Germany on 3 September 1939, they were still in the USA. Friends at once suggested that it would be safer to stay. They did not, but headed straight back to London.

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: GHS died in Switzerland, at the Salem Hospital in Bern, only three weeks before her husband followed her.
